monogr.title: A replie to M. Calfhills blasphemous answer made against the Treatise of the crosse, by Iohn Martiall, Bachiler of Lawe, and studient in diuinitie. Reade and regarde
monogr.author: Martiall, John

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE READER.
div.p:
HAuing reade and regarded the answer to the treatise of the crosse, and finding the scriptures falsified, the councells disauthorised, the fathers corrupted, the doctours miscōstrued, the sacraments prophanelye reported, the churche discredited, the vertuous sclaundered, S. Cyprian reiected asFol. 103 a blasphemous, 101 b Fabianus an holy martir refused as infamous, S. Dionyse Paules scholler condemned as suspicious, 132 a Helena a blessed saincte neglected as superstitious. S. Gregory as fabulous, 6. b Paulinus as zelous without knowledge, the fathers of the Nicene councell called68. a Asses, Nice 68. a maisters, and70. a Sinodicall men, their assemble an 182. a. insolēt, doltishe cōspiracie, dissembling at Nice,
their decrees impudent Fol. 163. b Fol. 17. a. vanities and idolatrous dedes and doctrines, the doctours vnworthied of auctoritie, as mē that had Fol. 120. b errours, men that thought Fol. 29. b. better than they wrote, mē that Ibidem. borowed of the cōmon custome impropre phrases, such as seeme to mayntayne an errour, men that were not so wel affectioned as they Fol. 89. a oughte, mē that in termes Fol. 175. b ouer shotte them selues, men that declined all, from the Fol. 23. a simplicitie of the Ghospell, To be short finding the crosse, which in the holy scriptures and auncient fathers is called,Apoca. 7. Signum Dei, Signum Matth. 24 filij hominis, Signum Cassio. in Psal. 4. coelestis Imperatoris, Theod. ca. 1. li 6. Trip. figura dominici trophaei, Chrisost. in demōst. cont. gent. Argumentum multae benedictionis, Aug. ca 3. de visit. in. venerabile monumentum, Salutare, Cyril. li. 6. cōt. Iulia. & Lactantius de passio. preciosum, venerabile lignum, Ephrē de poenit. viuificum signum, Cano. 73. Concil. Cōstā. in Trull. victoriae trophaeum, Lactā. li 4 c. 27. de vera sapi. c. 26. coelestis nota, maximum sublime & immortale signum, Aug ser. de cruce & lat. res honoris, mortis deuictae Cyril. hie ros. epist. ad Cōst Impe. trophaeum, Lactā. ca. 27. lib. 4 de vera sapiēt. & Aug. c 20 de cathe. ru. Signum passionis, Chris. ho. 55. 116. Mat. & Iusti. Tit. de Monac. Nouel col 1 Signum salutis nostrae, Chris ho 55. in 16. Mat. Signum communis libertatis, signum mansuetudinis & humilitatis domini, Amb li. 6 c. 4. de Sacr. Signum virtutis, & Paulin{us} epi. 11 ad Seuer. pignus aeternae salutis, the signe of God, the signe of the sonne of man, the signe of the heauenly Emperour, the figure of our lordes triumphe, a token of much blessing, an honorable monument, an healthfull, precious, and reuerend wood, a liuely signe, a triumphant banner of victorie, an heauenly marke, a most greate, high and immortall signe, a pearle of price, a signe of the conquest ouer death, a signe of Christes passion, a signe of our saluation, a signe of the delyueraunce of all mankinde, a signe of the meekenes, and humilitie of Christ, a signe of vertue and pledge of eternall saluation, to be likened toFol. 44. b. gallowes, to the helmet29. b. of hell, to the coniurers mace, and called a magicall25. b. inchauntemēt, an heathenish117. a. obseruance, a stumbling176. b stock, a128 a. stone of offence, a25. b. cause of sicknes, a106. a. dumbe God, a94 a. dead diuell, a3. a counterfeict of Serapis, and120 a. conquest against the Christians, and prayers of the church a sacrifice of the diuel, suffrages helps to hel, our sauiours counsels ordinances of the diuel, Christ no lawemaker and his Ghospell by consequent no lawe
I thought it good to contemne it, as a famous libel, ful of lyes,M. dormā in his preface. sclaunders, and blasphemies, and let it lye obscure with the authour, especially seing the superintendents, being demaunded, whether they would iustifie the saide booke, and all the doctrine contayned in it, haue geuen no signification nor notice of their liking, lest yf vpon their generall lyking, it shoulde be confuted, the ignominie should redounde vnto them, whereas nowe the whole shame lieth but in one pratīg Parrat,Prouer. 26 more woorthy to be contemned than answered.

But when I considered that saying of Salomō, Answer a foole accordinge to his foolishnes that he may not seme wyse vnto him selfe, I thought it good to examine the forsaid answer, and discouer the folly of it, that bothe the authour seing his vanities layed before his eies, might be asshamed of his arrogancie, ād with the {pro}ude peacocke, lookīg vpō his foule feete, cast downe his braggīg tayle ād abhorre his serpētine voyce, ād also the simple reader poysoned with the venemo{us} drugges, of his gay coloured, ād sweete sugered wordes, might haue a remedy to expel that infectiō, ād preseruatyue to beware of the like. VVherfore al his superfluities cast aside, and impertinēts loted out, I will bringe the chiefest and most principalst matters, that he treateth in his answer, to this examination. And that yow may the better vnderstand which are the wordes that M. Calfhill vseth either of scripture, Doctour, Councell, or his owne, I haue sett them in a distincte letter, and noted the place in the Margent where you shall finde them in his booke, as they are in effect.

And to begynne with the preface, his longe discourse there,M. Calf • intent in his preface. Fol 9. a tēdeth chiefly to proue that there shoulde be no images in churches. And for proufe of that, he brīgeth certayne places of scripture, as the 20. Exodus, where it is sayde: Thou shalt haue none other Gods before me. Thou shalt make vnto thy selfe no grauen image, nor any similitude that is in heauen aboue, or in the earthe beneath, or in the waters vnder the earth. Thou shalt not adore them, nor woorshippe them, And the 19. of Leuiticus, where it is saide. Nolite conuerti ad idola, turne not to Idolls, nor make vnto yower selfes, Gods
of metall, VVhat is forbidden by this cōmaundement. and suche like. VVhiche preceptes of God do onely inhibite the idolls of the gentils to be vsed amonge the Iewes who were so prone vnto the idolatrie, of the Gentills that they woorshipped caul • es, stocks, stones, catts, apes, brute beastes, and the sunne, moone, and starrs, for God. VVherfore God being a iealous God, a god that would haue the glorie of his name geuen to no creature on earthe, did forbid them, to make any grauen idol, or likenesse of any thinge, because they should not adore it,Exod. 32. and worship it for God, as the children of Israel did, when they sayd of the golden Caulfe, Hi sunt dij tui Israell, These are thy Gods o Israell. Yf it had bene his holy will, to haue forbidden absolutely all kinde of images,Exod 25. the images of Angells made and set in the mercy seate by the apoyntmēt of God. 3 Reg 7. Images of oxen and Lions in Salomons temple. he would neuer haue willed Moyses to make the twoe Cherubins vpon the mercy seate, in the Tabernacle. For he should haue geuen a precept contrary to his firste commaūdement. Neither would Salomon being in hye fauour with God at that time, haue made, and engraued the images of oxen, lyons, and Cherubins in the tēple which he made, to the honour and glorie of God. For in so doing he should haue greuouslye transgressed that lawe. For the Cherubins that Moyses made, were scuptile, a grauen image, the images of a certayne order of Angells: the oxen and Lyons had Similitudinem, the likenesse of a thing in earth. But let vs not erre. There is no alteration, no chaunge, nor contradictiō in God: he is allwayes one. VVherfore when he did forbid the Israelites, to make any grauen image, he did forbidde them to make it, because they should not take them to be Gods, nor adore them and woorshippe them for Gods. VVhen he willed Moyses to make the tabernacle, he willed those Cherubīs to be made,Paralip. 22 for a bewtie and furniture of his house, which that precepte did not inhibite: which Salomon vnderstanding caused those oxen,The ievves stamped Caesars image in his coyne. Lyons, and Angells, to be engraued, and portraicted in his temple. And seing he making that temple by the prouidence and commaundement of God, willed those images to be made in his temple, it is euident that the forsaide commaundement of God, did not inhibite all kinde of images, to be made, no not in the temple.

Besides this, the Iewes them selues, being very skillfull in their lawe, and scrupulouse in obseruing it, according to the lettre, stamped the image of Caesar in their coynes. And our Sauiour Christ seing it, did neuer reprehend them for it, which he woulde haue done, had it ben agaynst the lawe. But when he sawe the Coyne with the image of Caesar, he saide no more, but Geue vnto Caesar, Matt. 22. those thinges which are Caesars and to God those thinges that are Gods. Furdermore all Christian Emperours, princes, and gentle men would neuer haue engraued, nor sett in their ensignes, and Armes, Egles, Lyons, Lylies, Greyhoundes, Draggons, Faukons, horses, gotes, bulls, beares, Apes, and such like. For sculptile, is a grauen thing. And if all grauen thinges had ben by that precepte inhibited, they would neuer so generally haue practised it, nor with out feare of Gods indignation, hitherto haue cōtynued it. Ouer and aboue al this, Christ gaue an image of his countenāce to Veronica, and sent an other to Abgarus, Damasce. lib 4 cap. 17 de orthod. side. Euseb. lib. 7. cap. 14. histor. king of the Edissens. The Christians euē frō the begynning payncted both his images and the Apostles also, which were sculptile & similitudo, a grauē image, and the lykenes of a thinge. VVherfore seing Moyses at the commaundement of God, made the twoe Cherubins in the tabernacle, seing Salomon engraued in his tēple, oxen, lyons, and Cherubins, seing the Iewes stamped the image of Caesar in their Coynes, and were not reproued of Christ for them, seing Christen Emperours, princes, and gentle men sett Egles, Lyons, Lilies, dragons, greyhoundes, and such like in their armes, and were neuer controlled for yt, Seing the Christians, euen from the Apostles tyme, haue made the images of Christ and his Apostles, and thoughte to honour Christ and his Apostles by it, yt must nedes followe, that the precepte of God,VVhat images the L vve doth forbid. Non facies tibi sculptile, Thow shalt not make vnto thy selfe any grauen image, doth not absolutely forbid all kinde of images, but only such as were adored and worshipped, and that not simplye neither, but such as were adored ād worshipped for gods: such the lawe doth inhibite, such doth God forbid. And al such doe we Catholiques detest, accurse, and abhorre: and euer did.

VVe knowe our images to be but the worke of man: we
doe not worship, nor adore, nor honour the matter, wherof they are made. That which we adore and worship, is the thing represented by the image, which is either Christ him selfe, or some of his saynctes. And in honouring them as the frendes of God, we honour God, as the prince that honoureth an others prince his Ambassadour honoureth the prince in his Ambassadour.Heretikes calling the Christians images Idols, or denie Christ to be come, or discredite the prophets. Sopho. 2. Al idols destroyed by Christes coming. And if our newe Maisters will nedes haue the Christians images to be idolls, than either they must deny Christ with the Iewes to be come, or contemne the prophetts with the Samaritanes. For if Christ hath bē incarnate & redemed the worlde, then hath he according to the predictions of the prophetts destroyed all Idolls, and delyuered his church from them. For Sophonias said of Christ, He shall destroye all the godds of the earthe. Zacharie sayeth, I will destroy the names of Idolls out of the earthe, and they shalbe remembred no more. By the name of Idolls he vnderstādethe here honour and worship done to Idolls. Nowe yf Christ according to this prophecy, by his cumning destroyed all Idolls, and worshipps done vnto them, then will it followe, that the images of the Christians, are not Idolls, nor the honour and reuerence done vnto them, an honour and reuerence done vnto Idolls. Or yf it be, that either Christ by his cumming, did not destroye the idolls of the Gentils, or that the prophetts were not true, in their {pro}phecies. And one of these twoe they must graunte, spite of their beardes, vnlesse they wilbe worse thā Iulian the apostata. For he being otherwise an enemy of Christe, and of all Christians seing the deameanour of the faithfull beleauers,Lib. 6 cōt. Iulia. was forced to confesse that cessabant idola adorare, & colere as Cyrillus saieth: They ceased to adore and worship idols. But because he despited their religiō, and knewe not the secret mysteries of it, he layde to their chardge, (as these men do to ours) that they adored the wood of the Crosse. But howe fondly it was done, Cyrill sheweth at lardge, as the learned knowe, and he that is desirous to see and able to reade and vnderstand, may turne the booke, and finde. For the simple, it may suffice them to knowe, howe that Christ, by his cumming destroyed al wicked idolls, and grosse idolatrie of the Gentills, and taught vs a
true waye to worship God in spirite and truth, and that, the catholique church, hath euermore obserued that manner of worshipping of God, and euer taught that images, be deuoyd of all sense of them selues, and therfore worthy of no honour in respecte of them selues, but in consideration that they represent vnto vs Christe, and his sainctes.

Out of the newe Testament he quoteth these places:Fol 9. a Acto. 7.48. But the highest dwelleth not in temples made of handes, heauen is my seate, and the earth is my foote stoole, Acto. 15 28. It hath semed good to the holy Ghost and vs, to put no burdeyne vpon you besides these necessaries, that ye absteyne from thinges offred vp to false images, and bloud and strangled meate, and fornication. Rom. 1 And they changed the glorie of the vncorruptible God, into the likenesse of an image of a corruptible man, and of birdes, and foure footed, and creeping beastes.

p.hi: I wrote vnto you in an epistle that ye should not company with fornicatours of this worlde, nor with the couetouse,

nor with the extorcioners, nor with them that serue idolls. For thē must ye nedes haue gone out of this worlde, but nowe I write vnto you that you company not together. Yf he that is called a brother, be a fornicatour, or couetous,
p.note: Idolis seruiens. 1 Cor. 10 1 Cor. 14 Idolorum cultura 2 Cor. 6 14. Cōsensus tēplo Dei cū idolis Galat. 5.20. 1. Ioan 21. Simula chris. Acto. 7.48.
p.hi: or a worshipper of idolls or a rayler, or a drunckarde, or an extorcioner, with hym that is such a one, see that ye doe not eate. Flee from the woorshpping of idolls.

div.p: Drawe not the yoke with infidells, and a litle after that, what agreement hath a temple of God with idols? Be not druncke with wyne in which is ryott, but be filled with the holy Ghost, speaking vnto yower selues in hymnes and Psalmes and spirituall songes, singinge and making melodie to God in yower hartes, geuing thanckes allwayes for all, to God the father in the name of our lorde Iesus Christe. Litle children keepe yower selues from false and fayned images.

And all these places make not one iote against images. For
albeit God dwelleth not so in temples made with handes,Acto. 15.28. but that his power also is euery where without scripture, yet hath he bene worshipped, adored and honored in tēples made with handes. And as in the old Testament he commaunded the tabernacle to be made, and images of Cherubins in it, and Salomons temple, where both the Cherubins, and images of oxen liōs and such like were paynted: So hath he in the tyme of grace, by secret inspirations, and visions, commaunded churches to be builded, that the faithfull might resort vnto them, to honour prayse, and serue hym. And in those he hath willed the signe of our redemption, and crosse of Christe and images of sainctes to be erected and set vp. And yf yow aske me where this will, and commaundement of God is to be seene, I answere, it is to be sene in the decrees of the catholique church which is one body with Christe, directed and taughte by the holy Ghoste. It is to be sene in the holy fathers, by whome God speaketh vnto vs,In Psal. 46 as S. Augustine declareth, saying: God hath spokē many wayes, he hath spoken by Angells, by prophetis, by his owne mouthe, by his Apostles, by his faithfull seruantes, he speaketh: by so meane a man as I am he speaketh, when I speake any thing that is true. Ipse sonat vbique tangendo, modificando, inspirando, he sowndeth euery where, by touching, gouerning, and inspiring the hearte.

Furthermore albeit God hath forbidden vs to eate of thinges offred to idolls, yet hath he not forbidden vs to eate that which is offred vpon the aulter.1. Cor. 9. But prouided that he that serueth the aulter, shall take parte of the aulter. Or yf he had not, what reason hath this our protestants argument? VVe must not eate thinges offred to idolls, ergo we must haue no images? Consider it by a lyke. VVe must abstaine from fornication, ergo we must not haue the sounday kept holyday. As for the antecedent, it is a commaundemēt of God as well as the abstaining from thinges offred to idolls, and the consequent followeth as well as the first. Concerning the thing it selfe, as the church, notwithstanding God gaue a speciall precept to kepe holy the sabaoth day, aduētred to turne it into the sunday, because they woulde haue nothing common with the Iewes: So the same church, seing no
precepte of God forbidding the image of Christe and his Sainctes, to be had amongest Christen men, hath not only permitted, but also cōmaunded the said images, to be had in churches, and oratories. And seing it is so, we are as much bounde to obey the church in one, as in the other. To procede, what argument will he make, against images, of the wordes of S. Paule, either to the Romaines, Corinthians, or Galathians? Yf he say:Rom, 1. 1. Cor. 5. Galat. 6. M. Calfs argumēts. Some chaunged the glorie of the vncorruptible God into the likenes of an image, of a corruptible man, ergo all men did: we must not company with idolatours, ergo we must haue no images: we must flee from the woorshipping of Idolls: ergo we must worship no images, The temple of God hath no agrement with idolls, ergo the church hath no agrement with images: we must not be drunck with wyne, in which there is ryot, ergo we must not haue any images of sainctes, Keepe your selfes, from counterfettes: ergo haue no images, VVe will send hym to schole to learne Logicke agayne: For this is starke naughte, as euery yoūge puine that hath read his first principles may see.

But peraduenture M. Calf. trusting to the English doctours translation, who where he founde the worde Idolum in Latin,1. Cor. 5. idolis seruiens. False trāslation. translated it image, in Englishe, as where the Latin and Greke both saye: I wrote vnto you that you should not company with him that is a worshipper of idolls, he saide: I wrote vnto you, that you should not cōpany with hym that is a woorshipper of images, And where the Apostle saide: Fugite ab idolorum cultura, Flee from the worshipping of idolls, and agayne: Quis consensus templo Dei cum idolis? VVhat agrement hath the church of God with idolls, he said, howe agreeth the temple of God with images, M. Calf. I say, thought he might be bold to bringe the said places against images: but that warrant is insufficient, and auctoritie vnworthie so famous a reader: and argueth that he passeth not howe shamefully he corrupteth the scripture to deceaue the simple people. VVherfore to make him vnderstande his folly,The difference betvvene an Idol and an image. I will declare for his furder instruction, what difference there is betwene an idoll, and an image. The word idol is deryued of the
Greke nowne 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
species, Cice. libr. 15. epist. Fa. Cassia. because it sheweth and pretendeth a bare shape and voyde figure of a thinge, wheras in dede there is no such thinge at all. VVherupon that which the Greekes called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 idol, the Latins called, Spectrum, and it is taken for those pillers, counterfeicts and images, which were erected to represent that which is falsely beleaued to be a God.Lib. 7. quest. su{per} Iudic. ca. 41. Idolum. 1. Cor. 8. Sonnius Demonst. lib. 2. ca. 5. VVherfore S. August calleth, idolum falsi Dei simulachrum, an idol the forged image of a false and fayned God. In which there is no power, no vertue, nor any thing but mere vanitie, as apeareth by S. Paule, where he sayeth: Idolum nihil est, the idoll is nothing. That is to say: Nihil habet in se eius quod creditur numinis et veritatis. It hath nothing in it of the power and truth which it is beleaued to be. And in this sense, it is taken in the scriptures, that M. Calf. alleadgeth, and in all the fathers which write against the grosse superstition, and wicked impietie of the Gentills for worshipping of idolls.

The Christians images cā not be called idols.As for our images they can neither be called Simulachra, feyned counterfeites, nor idolls. For first they are not erected to represent vnto vs any thing, as God, nor beleaued to haue any vertue or power in them as God. Thirdly they represent, no false nor lying thing, but that which they represent vnto vs is true. As the image of Christe vpon the crosse in the forme of man, representeth vnto vs, that he was a mortall man, and put to death for our redemption. The image of our ladie representeth vnto vs the mother of Christ, in whome he was incarnate, and made man. And so likewise of other sainctes, wherupon an image either paincted or engraued in wood, Vide Quītinū Heduū in Synod. Gang impressam Paris. 1560. Imago. Actio. 4. 2. Nicae. stone, or metall, is a true representation of a thinge: or a figure, likenesse, and shape of him that is portraicted either in the picture, or in the engraued worke. It is as Germanus an holy patriarke of Constantinople declareth, a description of the stoutenes of holy men, who resisted synne vnto deathe. It is a representation of holy vertue, and dispensation of grace, geuen vnto them. It is an admonition and instruction to glorifie God, whome they serued in this life. And this hath nothing that resembleth the nature of the Iewes idols, or gentills counterfeites, as is declared before.

VVe Christen men call not ower images Gods, we geue thē no diuine honour, we thinck no power, nor heauenly thing to
consist in them. VVe haue no hope, nor affiance of helpe and succour from them, as the Iewes had of their golden Calfe, and gentills of the Counterfeictes of Iuppiter, Mars, Apollo, Venus, and such like. Our trust is in God, and hope in the mightines of his power, who made both heauen and earth.Psal. 95. Hī we acknowledg to be our lord ād God, and none but him. Oēs dii gentiū, daemonia, Al the Gods of the gētils are diuels. VVherfore to al that thīke other wise of the catholikes ād take their images to be Idolls, we will cry Anathema, with the fathers of Nice.Act. 6. Nicae. 2. And to al that thīcke we worship thē as God, or geue honour vnto thē, due only to god, we wil say with the good father Epiphanius, O insanientē linguā. O mad and raging tōgue, edged like a sharpe sworde full of poyson. It is but a fable of the gētils, ād inuentiō of the diuel, and worke of Sathā. No Christen man geueth Latriam, Acto. 6. Nicae. 2. diuine honour and seruice to any creature on earth. Latria nostra est in spiritu & veritate. Our honour and seruice dewe vnto God, is in spirite, and truth.What adoratiō and vvorship is geuen to images Genes. 23. Genes. 33. Genes. 42.43. Exod. 18 2. Reg ca. vlti. The adoration, worship and honour, that we geue vnto images is but aulia, that is a seruice, which one creature oweth vnto an other, and is expressed by doing reuerence and honour vnto a man, or some other earthly thinge, either by putting of the cappe, bowinge the knee, humbling the bodie, kissing the hād, or such like. In this sort Abrahā adored the people of Heth, Iacob adored his brother Esawe, Iosephs brothers adored hī, lying flat on the groūde. Moyses adored Iethro his father ī lawe. Areuma Iebu seus adored Dauid with his face flatt vpō the grounde, Iacob adored the toppe of Iosephs rod. And after like sorte doe we Christen men, reuerence, honour, and woorship one other.

VVhen we meete together we put of the cap, we bowe the knee, we humble the bodie, we offer to kisse the hand. In like manner when we receaue the kinges letters, we put of our capps. VVhen we come into the chamber of presence, and see the cloth of estate, we shewe a kinde of reuerence and honour vnto it, not respecting the pa{per} and waxe, nor silken clothe, or golden chaire, but the prince that wrote it, and kinge that sate vnder that cloth of estate. Right so when we see the image of Christe, or any Sayncte, we put of our cappes,Haeb. 11. we make courtesy,
we bowe,Why vve bovve to the crosse and image of Christ we cappe, we kneele, and shewe such external reuerence, and honour, not because it is made of siluer and gold, or curiouslye wroughte, or sette with pearle, or fynely paynted, but because it representeth vnto me Christ and his passion, his sainctes and theyr patience, constancy and martirdome. And yf it be idolatrie for me or any Christiā man, to do this, thē it is idolatrie to reuerence my princes image, to vaile my bonnet when I receaue her lettre, to shewe reuerence when I come in sighte of her clothe of estate. For both haue one respecte. The one to the first Sampler represented by the image, the other to the prince that occupieth that seate, and gaue out that seale. And yf heretikes do not vnderstand this to be the doctrine of the Catholike churche, they shewe them selues very ignoraunte and vnskilfull in the Councells. For the fathers haue approued it. And of many to recite a fewe,

Images made in remembrance of Saincts. Stephanus B. Bostro writeth thus. God hath cast away and condemned the idolatrie of the Gentills, because they were counterfeictes of of diuells, we make images in remembraunce of Saynctes. Of whom yow saye? Forsoth of Abraham, Moyses, Elias, Esay, Zacharie, and other prophets, Apostles, and holy Martirs, who were persequuted for christes sake, that euery man that beholdeth them in the image may remembre them, and glorifie God, who honoured them. For honour and worship is sitting for them, for their righteousnes, that euery one, who seeth them, may be drawne to an imitatiō, of their good workes. But what honour of adoratiō is this? Images paincted and vvorshipped. Lib. 5. Apolo pro Christia. cont Iudeos habet. act. 4 Nicae. 2. Ezech. 40 & 41. 3. Reg. 6. & 7. verely no other thē suche as we vse, amōgest our selues, saluting one an other for honour ād loue. And a litle after, reasonnīg the matter he cōcludeth ād sayeth. By this it is very manifest, that the images of saītes who are the seruantes of God, are payncted, worshipped and adored.

Leontins bisshop of Neapolis in Cypres, prouing out of the old Testament, that God commaunded images to be made, as the Cherubins, which were images of Angells, Lyons oxen, palme trees, men, and such like, sayeth vnto the Iewe: Yf thou dost reproue me for images, reproue God him selfe, who commaunded these to be made, in remembrance of those thinges which we haue. And when the Iewe replied and said. The similitudes or images were not adored as God, The Christian awnswered. Yow say well, for with vs the images, figures,
and pictures of Saynctes are not worshipped as Gods. For if they worshipped Gods in the wood of the images, they would not burne the image, when the forme, and printe of it were gone. For my parte (saietn he) as twoe pieces of wood hauing the figure of the crosse are ioyned together, I adore the figure for christes sake: The figure of the crosse vvorshipped for Christes sake, and not the vvood nor metal when those pieces are separated, I cast them away and burne them. And as he that receaueth a commission or placket frō the Emperour, by kissing the seale worshippeth not the waxe, letters, or lead, but geueth that honour and reuerence to the Emperour: So we that are children of christen men, adoring the figure of the crosse, do not not adore the nature of the wood, but we looking vpon the seale, ringe, figure, and Christ him selfe, salute and adore him by this figure, who was crucified vpon it. Thus much Leontins, and much more in the same sense worthy of all men to be noted and read.Libr. 7. epist. 53. S. Gregorie wrting to Secundinus who desired to haue the images of Christ, S. Peter, and S. Paule, sent him, sayeth: I knowe, yow desire not the image of our Sauiour for that intent, that you will woorship it as a God, but that by remembraunce of it, yow may be feruent in the loue of God. And we do not fall downe before it, as before God, but we adore him, whome by the image we remēbre either borne, either to haue suffred, or sitting in his throne. Lib. 4 ca. 12. de orthod fide. Damascene sayeth, we adore the figure of the pretiouse and lyuely crosse, albeit it be made of an other matter, not worshipping the matter (for God forbid that). But the figure, as the signe of Christ. To be shorte, to declare the doctrine of the churche in this poynte, Gratian, (whome yow so much spite and malice) reciteth this Canon out of the syxt Synode. The Christians call not the reuerend images Gods,
De cōsec. dist. 3. cap. venerabiles.
The sixth Synode. The 7 general coūcel.
Actio. 7. Images cōmaunded to be set in churches.
nor serue them as God, nor put hope of saluation in them, nor looke for the iudgement that is to come of them, but they worship and adore them, for the memory and reuerence of the originals and first samplers, but they serue them not with diuine honour, nor any other creature. The seauenth geneall councell sayeth. VVe conclude that images be had and set vp in churches &c. that by this beholding and seing of images, all that looke vpon them may come to the memory, remembraunce, and desire of the first samplers, and geue vnto them a gentle salutation and courtiouse kinde of adoration, not adoration dewe vnto God, according to our faithe, but such as we geue to the figure of the reuerend and lyuely crosse, and Ghospells of
Christ &c. for the honour of the image redoundeth to the first sampler, and he that adoreth an image, adoreth the thing described in the image.

VVherfore seing it is so? what honestie is in this man, that bringeth the places of scriptures and fathers, that speake against the idolls which the seduced Iewes and Gentills worshipped and adored as Gods, and toke for Gods, against the images of the Christians which we professe to be no Gods, nor of any diuine ād heauēly power? Yea what Christian charitie is in his hearte that ceaseth not to vpbraie vs with grosse idolatrie that are redemed with the death of Christ, and brought out of thraldome of the diuell, and such abhomination, as the gentills vse, by his passion, and haue learned to adore him in spirite and truth, and defye all idolls, and accursed idolatours? The diuel hī selfe could say no more. But let it be their Euangelicall charitie, what reason is there in this saying?

Fol. 15. b Calf. An image can not be made of Christ except it be a lying image: for Christ is god and man. And since of the Godhead which is the most excellent part, no image can be made, it is falsely called the image of Christ: and they that do any honour vnto it, are mere Idolatours, making Christe therby inferiour to his father, cleauīg only to his humanitie, wheras we should so honour the sonne as they honour the father? Ioan. 5. Mart. VVould any be sides a scourer of old errours, and reuyuer of canckred heresies haue made the like? This was one of the greatest reasons, that the image breakers made in their conuenticle and conspiracy of Constantinople. And seing M. Calf. boroweth it of them, I might condemne him as an heretike with them. But that the worlde may see, what foolish fansies they haue that impugne images,Actio 6 Nicae. 2. The heretickes obiections I will lay forthe the answers that Epiphanius made for whole councell of Nice to like obiections, and then frame one to this. The heretikes obiected this in effecte as M. Calf. doth, and said: Christe is God and mā: Therfore yf you make an image of Christe, it must be an image of God and man. And yf that be true, then must either his deitie be circumscribed, or his vnitie be confounded. Epiphanius answered.

This worde Christe doth signifie the deitie and humanitie (that is) both the perfecte natures of Christ. Epiphani{us} ansvver. According to that nature in which he was seene, Christen men haue learned to paincte his image, and not according to that nature in which he was inuisible: for that can not be described. For we haue heard out of the Gospell, that no man euer sawe God. Ioan 1. 1. Ioan. 4. Therfore when Christ is paincted in his humaine nature, as the truth of the thing sheweth, Christen men professe and acknowledge that they shape the image that they see, to the first sampler according to the name, and not according to essence, or substance, The image of Christ paincted as he vvas man. that is (to make it playner) they professe to payncte Christ, as man only, and not as God and man. These lighte losells teache that there is no difference betwene the image, and the first sampler, that is betwene the bare image, and the thing represented by the image, et in diuersis substātijs idētitatē substātiae indicāt and in diuerse substances, shewe an idenditie of substance. Agayne he sayeth: No man is so madde that saying the humaine nature may be circumscribed goethe about by that, to circumscribe the nature which can by no meanes be circumscribed. Christ as he was man, was in Iury, and Galile. As he was God, he is in euery place, and contynueth, not able by any meanes to be circumscribed. Yf when he lay wrapte in swadeling clothes in the manger, his diuinitie was enwrapped by the nature of his humanitie, then shall his diuinitie, that is vncircumscriptible, be circumscribed in a coloured image, but yf his diuinitie was not enwrapped there, in the clothes, nor can his diuinitie be circumscribed here in the image. I would they would acknowledg and call to rememaraunce that saying of holy S. Dionyse, in his Hierarcihe. VVhere he saieth:S. Dyonise. Non est exacta similitudo causatis & causis, habent enim causata causarum contingentes imagines. Ipsae vero causae secundū proprij principij rationē exemptae sunt & supereminēt. There is no exacte or perfect likenesse betwene thinges that are caused, and the causes them selues. For the thinges caused haue the accident images or likenesse of the causes. The causes them selues, are exempte and doe ouerpasse all, according to the nature of their owne first beginning. And by this we may see, that Christ being God and man, may be payncted, as man, albeit he cā not be payncted as God, because euery image is made to the imitation of the name, and not according to the nature and substance of the represented.

Another obiection of theirs with which M. Calfhill also chardgeth the catholiques was this: To make an image af Christe in his humaine nature, as he walked here in earthe etc. is wicked and sauoring of the heresie of Nestorius.
Ansvver To this Epiphanius answered: The Christians knowing Christ to be God, paynte him as he was made man, and besides reiecte and cast from them all idle fansies. And receauing playnly, and simply, all thinges that are delyuered of the church, and beholding pictures or images, they conceaue nothing in their minde, but that which is signified by them. For when they behold in the picture that the virgin hath brought forthe a sonne, The meditations of true Christiās vvhē they see the image of Christ. and the angell and sheapeardes standing by, they thincke with them selues, that God is made man, and borne for our saluation. And that they acknowledg saying: He that is without fleshe, is nowe incarnate and borne in fleshe, he that is vnable to be touched, is nowe touched and felt. And so they acknowledge and confesse him to be one, perfecte in his humanitie and deitie. As for Nestorius, Nestorius heresie. he made two sonnes, vnum verbum patris, alterum Filium virginis. One the worde of the father, an other the sonne of the virgin. But true Christians confesse Christ their lorde, They do vvel that pay act the image of Christ. and God, to be but one sonne. And when they paynte his image as he was incarnate and made mā, they are knownē to doe very well and godly. For God the sonne bing made man, was conuersant with vs in fleeshe. The deitie is not cōsidered payncted: for no man euer sawe God. For he can not be paincted, sene, or comprised, but only his humanitie. For we knowe Christe to be of twoe natures, and in twoe natures, that is of humaine and diuine, ioyntly without diuision. One of them is vnable to be payncted, the other able to be payncted, is considered in one Christe.
In vvhat an image must be like the first sampler.
The soule of a man not of any sought in his image
And the image is not like the first sampler according to his substāce, but only in respecte of name and disposition of lyneaments expressed by the partes of the bodie. For when a paynter, paynteth the image of a man, no man requireth or seeketh the soule in the image. And verily the difference of the soule of man, and the diuine nature is seuered. The diuine nature is vncreated, and without all tyme. The soule of man is created, made in tyme, and framed by the diuine nature. Furder: No man that is wyse, seing the image of man, euer thought that the man was seuered from his soule by the paincter. For the image is not only depriued of the soule, but of the substāce of the bodie, as fleeshe, musculles, synowes, bones, bloud, fleame, choler, and humours, the mixture wherof can not be sene in the image. For
yf it could be sene in the image, we would call it a man, and not an image.

As for the deniyng or cōfounding of bothe natures, by paynting Christ as man, he sayeth thus in effecte. The talke which they haue of denying and cōsounding the diuine and humayne nature, hath no truth. For the image is one thing, and the proportion and originall another. What is to be loked for in an image. Nor any man that wise is, will seeke the properties of the originall in the image. For true reason seeketh nothing ells in an image, but a communitie of the name, whose image it is. It knoweth not the substāce of the original. Thus much Epiphanius. Nowe to come to M. Calfhills reason. VVe deny his principle, and require him to proue, according to his promisse, by scripture, councell, and auncient father, that because Christ is both God and man, Fol. 1 • . b an image can not be made of him, except it be a lying image. For Christ may be payncted in the forme and shape of a man, as he walked here in earth, and died on the crosse, albeit his godhead which is the most excellēt part, can not be comprised in any image. Neither are they lyers, that call any such picture the image of Christe, Fol 15. b They are not liere nor idolaters that call the image made to represent christ, the image of Christ. neither they mere idolaters that woorship it. For it is not necessarie in an image, that there be an exacte similitude in all proportions. Nor it is required, that the image be like the originall and first sampler, according to the substance, but only in respecte of name and disposition of the partes of the bodie. VVherfor yf Christe be payncted in the habite of man, either as he waulked here on earth, or as he died on the crosse, or as be roose from the dead and ascended to heauen, it may welbe said this is the image of Christe, although the true forme and proportion of his body be not knowne to vs.

As for his sentence adiudging them mere idolaters, that honour that image, it is but rashe, foolish, and ignorant, and argueth that he knoweth not, who be idolaters.VVho are idolaters. Lib. 10. ca. 6. de Trin. Therfore for his furder instruction, I will tell him. S. Augustine sayeth: Idololatrae dicuntur qui simulachris eam seruitutem exhibent quae debetur Deo. They are called idolaters, who geue that seruice to false images which is dewe to God.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . The seruice dewe to God (called of the Greciās 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) consisteth principallie in thre thinges, to wit, in acknowledging
him to be lorde of all lordes, maker and creatour of all thinges, and geuer of all goodnesse to man. Next in louing him with all our heartes with all our soules, and with al our power. Then in offerīg vnto him sacrifice of prayer, thāckes geuing, and the pretious bodie, and bloud of his sonne, Iesus Christ. This honour and seruice was neuer geuen by Christen man to images. The honour and worship which the churche alloweth to images, is no other, but a reuerent putting of the cap, bowing, kneeling, kissing, or such like, which, seing it hath bene done, and may be done to creatures, we are no more idolaters, for vsing the like to any image, than you are for kneeling to the prince, for putting of yower cap to the cloth of estate, for kissing the Quenes seale, or bowing to yower frend when you meete him.

Fol 15. b Fol. 16. a A sclaūderaus cauil Christ not made inferiour to his father by any Paynting of imagesVVhere he sayeth: that we by making an image of Christe, make him inferiour to his father, and cleaue only to his humanitie, it is but a mere sclanderouse cauill. For the making of an image, is the worke of mās hand, and by such worke Christ can not be made inferiour to his father. VVhen Christ walked here on earth, the disciples honoured him, and wayted vpō him, and serued him as man, his mother attended vpon him, the Maries and other holy woemen followed him as man. Mathaeus and Zachaeus receaued him into their houses as mā: and because they did serue him, honour him, and followe him as man, did they therfore deny him to be God? and make him inferiour to the father, or cleaue only to his humanitie? No sir: In like manner when we payncte him as man, engraue his image as man, or portraicte him vpon the crosse crucified as man, doe we deny him to be God, or make him inferiour, to the father or cleaue only to his humanitie? VVhat extreame folly is in this follishe fantasie?A questiō to M. Calf. Let me aske M. Calf. this question. VVhen you made and penned yower last sermō, did you write the name of Christe in it or no? Yf you did, you did it in paper and yncke, and because paper and yncke can not conteyne the power of God,Vvhether he that vvriteth the name of Iesus in ynck paper maketh hym inferiour to his father. nor diuinitie of Christe, did you deny Christ to be God, or make him inferiour to his father, and cleaue only to his humanitie? Answer M. Calf. And yf you by writing his name in yncke and paper,
do not deny him to be God, nor make him inferiour to his father, no cleaue only to his humanitie, no more doe we by making his image in colours, or in any kīde of metal. But as you by writīg his name in yncke, ād paper, doe by reading or pronoūcing of it trāsmitte him by the eare into the minde, and there cōceaue him to be bothe God ad mā: Euē so we by payncting him as man, doe by the eie transmitte him into the hearte, and there adore and worship hym as God, and mā, of equal substāce with the father, and neuer separate his diuine and humaine nature.

But put case in paynting Christ as man, we did make hym inferiour to the father? Are we therefor idolaters M. Calf? Did not Christ say, Pater maior me est? My father is greter than I am? Doth not the Catholique church sing in the crede made by Athanasius, Ioan. 14. Minor patre secundum humanitatem? In Symbolo Athanasij. Christ is lesser than the father according to his humanitie? And if Christ be inferiour to his father as he was man, is it not lawfull for vs to thincke so of him? And if it be lawfull to thincke so of him, is it not laufull to paynte him so, and set hym foorth in a picture as man and yet committe no idolatrie? Answer directly sir. Vnlesse you quitte your self the better, either yow must recant with greate shame, or denie the gospel of Christ, and doctrine of the church with impudent arrogancie. For they manifestly teache that Christ according to his humanitie is inferiour to his father. And that being true, it is no idolatrie nor to thincke hym nor make hym in that sense inferiour to his father.

Thus for that obiection, wherin yf I haue bene somewhat longe, pardon me (gentle reader). It is all to make the matter playne to thy capacitie. Yf I had to doe with M. Calf. alone in the schooles, I would haue denied his argument, and required his ministershippe to haue made these consequēts good. Christ is God, and man, ergo there can be no image made of hym as man. There can be no image of the godhead, ergo there can be true image of Christ, as man, ergo they that honour it, are mere idolatours, making Christe therby inferiour to his father, and cleauing only to his humanitie. And when he had iustified
them by scripture, councell, or auncient father, or any good reason, I would haue geuen him the victorie, and so will I yet, vnlesse I cōuince and impugne his reason with better. In the meane tyme we will beleaue the ordinaunces of the Catholique church, and boldly affirme that as man consisting of body and soule,An image of man may be paynted although the soule cā not be expressed. Fol. 16. a may be payncted, albeit the soule which is the chifest part can by no arte be expressed: Euen so our Sauiour Christ may be paynted, engraued, and represented by an image in the forme and shape of man, albeit the diuinitie which is the cheifest parte be vncircumscriptible, indiuisible, incomprehēsible and vnable by any meanes to be expressed. But the reason is nothing like, quoth M. Calf. For the soule may be seuered from the bodye as daily by death we see by experience. Nor is it impietie to thincke vpon, or behold the shape of a man without a soule, but the diuinity of Christ can not be separated from his humanitye. Nether is it lawfull to imagine an humanitye without a diuinitie lest we fall into the heresy of Nestorius. To reproue that he varieth farre from all good reason, aske him first (good readers) whether our sauiour Christ died not for vs, as man, and whether he gaue not vp the ghost, and lay in the gaue as mā?The soule of Christ seuered from his bodie at his death. and if he cōfesse it, (as he must) yf he be a Christen man, then aske him whether the soule of Christ was not seuered at that tyme from the bodie, and yf he acknowledge it, then aske him whether it be impietie for vs to thincke that the soule of Christ was seuered from his body? Yf he accompte it none, then must he seeke for a newe reason to proue, that albeit man consisting of body and soule may paynted, yet Christ consisting of his humane and diuine nature, can not be paynted as man, for this will not serue.

Agayne whereas we talke of paynting, aske him why he chaungeth the state of question,M Calf fleeth frō the question. and runneth to thinckīge, and where we speake of engrauing, why doth he runne to ymagining, and from the hande why doth he flee to the heart? ower cōtrouersie is not whether the minde may thincke, or the heart imagine the humanitye of Christ, without the diuinitye, but
whether the hand may paynte him, as man, not withstanding it is not able to paynt his diuinitie. And to this he sayeth nothing, worthy the hearing, nor can yf he would. For looke howe lawful it is for him to haue his wiues image or coūterfeicte of his frende, in his house: So lawfull it is for vs, to haue the image of our sauiour Christ in the shape of mā, both in the church and house. Nor doe we Christen men,Christen mē neuer separate the diuinitie of Christ frō his humanitie. when we behold that image separate in hearte and thoughte, the diuinitie, from the humanitie, nor thincke of Christ as only man, but we beleaue him, we acknowledg him, we confesse him to be God and man, equall with his father in substāce, and euerlasting in diuyne Maiestie with him. This with heart we beleaue, and this with mouthe we confesse, and worship him in spirite, and truthe, whome we knowe to be re{pre}sented by that image. Nor was there euer Christen man, allowed of the church, that thoughte contrary. VVherfore M. Calf. may seeke other, whome he may vpbraide with the heresie Nestorius, for paynting the image of Christe as man. For that sclaunder can not light vpon the Catholiques.

His other twoe reasons that followe are witlesse.Fol. 16 a M. Calfs reasons. For who would say as he dothe, Christe caried his fleshe vp vnto heauē with him, no more to be knowne according to fleshe, ergo we fleashly creatures do fall from his will, when we make a counterfeict of his mortall fleshe, whereas his is glorified? Agayne vnknowne it is what was the forme and countenaunce of Christ. Therfore as sone as an image of Christ is paīted by and by a lye is made? I assure you no simple logisoner,The pro{per}ties of the original not to be sought in an image. The properties of the example not to besought in the image much lesse a solemne reader of Poules owght to vse suche baggage for very shame. It is but paultry. For it is not necessarie (as I said before out of Epiphanius) that the image be like the originall, and first sampler in substance: nor any man that wise is, will seeke the properties of the originall, in the image. For true reason seekethe nothing in an image, but the communitie of the name, and disposition of lyneamentes expressed by the partes of the bodie. Yf it should haue all the {pro}perties and qualities of the originall, then should it be no image, but the thinge it self. As if the
picture which the payncter draweth, should haue fleash, bloud musculls, synowes, life and other properties, and qualities that rest in the originall, we would no longer accompte it an image but a man. VVherefor we tell M. Calf. that in this case he is lurdely deceaued, and that vnlesse he proue by scriptures, councels and fathers, that all the properties of Christe and his blessed fleashe, must be expressed in his image, he shalbe a lyer for saying, It is a lying image, and not the image of Christ.

Nowe touching his authorities brought out of Epiphanius, Irenaeus, and S. Augustine, ye shall vnderstand that he belyeth Epiphanius and Irenaeus, and falsifieth S. Augustine. For neither did Epiphanius rent a paynted clothe wherin was the picture of Christ or some saincte,Fol. 141. b as shall apeare hereafter, in the 5. Article: Neither did Irenae{us} reproue the heretikes called Gnostici, for that they caried about the image of Christe. Irenaeus writeth thus of those accursed heretikes.Irenaeus lib. 1. c. 14. The Gnosticks. They cal thēselues Gnostickes, they haue also certayne payncted images, and certayne made of other matter, sayīg that it was the shape ād {pro}portiō of Christ made of Pilat, at what tyme Ies{us} was cōuersant here with mē, ād those images they crowned with garlādes, ād set thē foorthe with the images of the Heathē Philosophers (that is to say with the image of Pythagoras, Plato, Aristotle, ād others) ād did other solemnities aboute them as the Gentills doe. Thus much Irenaeus of that matter. And where is there in all this, any one woorde which reproueth the Gnosticks, for that they caried about the image of Christ? Irenaeus doth but only declare the facte, and addeth no wordes of reproufe, nor can it be gathered of his wordes or any circumstances that he reproued them for that. The cause why he reproued them,VVhat Irenaeus reproued in those heretiks. was because they placed the image of Christ with the image of Pithagoras, Plato, Aristotle and other heathen Philosophers, and vsed such solemnities and obseruatiōs aboute them as the Gentills did. And this was the thinge that Irenaeus reproued, and not the hauing and carying aboute the image of Christe.

S. August. falsified.VVhere he sayeth, that S. Augustine alloweth M. Varro, affirming that relligion is most pure without images, and citeth
for his credit in the margent, De ciuitate Dei lib. 4. cap. 3, Ye shall vnderstand that in all that chapiter S. Augustine doth no so much as mētion M. Varro. That which he meaneth is in the 31. chapiter of the saide booke. There he talketh of M. Varro, and commendeth him for a wise man, but these very wordes, that religion is most pure without images, VVordes attributed to S. Augustine not soūde in hym. are not to be founde in the whole chapiter: he sayeth: The Romaines contynued more then an hundred and seuentie yeares, s • ne simulachro, without an idoll, without a false and fayned images and yf that had contynued, he sayeth: Castius dij obserua ••• . The Gods had bē better honoured. Agayne he thought, castius obseruari sine simulachris religionē, that religion would haue bene more reuerently and better obserued without idolls, or fayned images. That is to say, he thought that yf they had had no idolls, nor false images of Gods, they would haue thought better of God, and not haue beleaued their idolls, their stockes, and stones to haue ben Gods. But what is this to that which M. Calf. maketh S. Augustine father vpon M. Varro, that religion is most pure without images? Can the hauing of images make religiō worse, and the not hauing of them make it better? That were worthy the learning of so fyne a fansier. VVise mē thincke that religion, which (as S. Augustine sayeth) is cultus diuinitati, Religion. Lib. 10. ca. 1. de ciuit. Dei. vel deitati debitus, a worship dewe vnto the diuinitie, or godhead, contynueth alwayes one, and as the logisioners say, non suscipit magis & minus, is no more a worship this day, then it was yesterday, no more purer this day, then it was yesterday. And whether we haue images, or no images, religion shalbe most pure alwayes.

All that M. Varro sayde, and S. Augustine reported in the forsaide place is,The effect of M varro his saying. that yf the Romaines had had no idolls nor fayned images, men would haue thought better of God, and haue serued him better, men would haue kept religion better. Men that knewe not God, nor could lifte vp their eies to heauen, and conceaue that there was a God, would haue quickly learned that there had bene a God, yf they had had no earthly idolls, which they might haue honoured, ād worshipped as God. But what is this to vs, that knowe God, worship God, and are deliuered frō such ignorāce, superstition,
and idolatrie by our sauiour Christe throughe the great mercy of God? howe dare you crake M. Calfhil that our religion is corrupted with them which we vse not? The Christians when the Iewes would not geue them the body of S. Polycarpe, thinking they would forsake Christ and worship him, said:Euseb. lib. 4. cap. 15. The miserable wretches knowe not, that we can not forsake Christ that suffred death for the saluation of the world, nor worship any other, because we knowe the true God that must be worshipped. So say we to these protestantes that thincke we committe idolatrie, forsake Christe, and corrupte his religion with images. And in deede they shewe them selues very wretches, that haue so vyle imaginations of any Christen man.

There is none vnlesse he be madde, but cā tell a differēce betwene a dead and senselesse thinge, and that which hath both life and soule. Euery childe yea euery beast knoweth, that it is not God, whome they see, as M. Calf. alleadgeth out of S. Augustine:In Psal. 36 & 113. which wordes although in parte they be true, yet are they not all S. Augustines wordes, nor these that followe, neither in such sort as they be alledged. Marke and you shall se. M. Calf. putteth them downe thus. Euery child, yea euery beast knoweth that it is not God that they see. Fol. 15. a VVherfore then doth the holy Ghost so oftē warne vs of that which all men knowe? he answereth thus. For when the images, are placed in temples in honorable sublimitie, and begynne once to be worshipped, forth with breadeth the most vile affection of errour. S. Augustine talking there of the Gentills idolls, and declaring, that the God which they worshipped, was blinde, deafe, dumbe, immoueable, vnsensible, deade, and worse than the dead, sayeth: O my dearly beloued brethren, what is more manifest than this? what is more euidēt? what childe being asked, is not able to answere, that it is certayne that the images of the Gentills haue mouthes, and will not speake, eies and will not see, and the rest which the word of God hathe adioyned? VVhy then doth the holy Ghost so earnestly prouide to insinuate and inculcate those thinges, as it were to ignorants? as though they were not most open and well knowne to men, but because he signifieth by the
shape and proportion of the membres, which we haue bene accustomed naturally to see in other, and see in our selues. Albeit as they affirme in some signe made cunningly, and set vp in an hye place, when it begynneth to be adored and honoured of the multitude, it breadeth the most filthiest affection of errour, that because he findeth not in the fayned image, a lyuely mouing, he beleueth that there is some diuine power in it, yet for all that being deceaued with the shape, and moued with the auctoritie of wise masters, and obedient people, he thincketh the image, that is like a lyue bodie, is not without some lyuely inhabitour: vpon this, such like affection of men inuiteth wicked diuells to possesse the Gentills idolls, by whose manifest deceites resting there, diuerse manifest errours are sowed and multiplied.

Therfore in other places also the holy scripture doth watche diligently against these idolls, nor let any man say, The scripture agaīst idols. when these forged images are irrided, I woorship not this visible thinge that we see, but the power that lieth secret within. But those powers the scriptures condemne: Quoniam dij gentium, daemonia, because the Gods of the Gentills are diuells. And a litle after he sayeth: They seme vnto them selues to be of a more purer religion, which say, I worship not the image, nor the diuell, but by the bodely shape, I see the signe of that thing which I must worship. What the Gētils vnderstode by their idols. So in good soothe they take and vnderstande their images, that by one they say, the earthe is signified, wherupon they are wont to call the temple of the earthe, by an other they signifie the sea, as by the image of Neptune, by another the fyre, as by the image of Vulcane, by another the day starre, as by the image of Venus, by another the sunne, by another the moone, to whose images they geue names, as they did to the image of the earth. By another they signifie this starre, and that starre, this creature, and that creature, for we are not able to expresse all. VVordes not in S. Augustine. Thus farre S. Augustine touching that which maister Calf. alleageth. And in all this, where are those wordes. For when images are placed in temples, which he fathereth vpon S. Augustine? They are not there, nor any one woorde against the images of the Christians.

All his discourse in that place is against the false images of Neptune, Vulcane, Iuno, Venus, and the creatures which they did worship as gods, as the sunne, the moone, the starres, the earthe the sea, and such like. VVhich being so, what honesty is there in
this minister to falsifie S. Augustine, and turne that to the Christians, which he spoke of the Gentils, and to alleage that against their images which was spokē against idolls? S. Augustine him selfe, best interpreter of his owne wordes, geueth vs to vnderstand, in that place rehearsed, that the present Psalme which he handled, and other places of scripture spoke against those fayned and forged counterfeites of the Gentills, and idolls, which they worshipped. Yet notwithstanding he is so impudent, that he sayeth:Fol. 15. a An impudent lye. Thus all the doctours haue thoughte the commaundement to extende to vs, and that ower images are forbidden by it. And of all the doctours, in this place, he hath recited, but thre, and those thre make nothing for him, as in parte you see, and shall see furder hereafter. But to oppose him a litle better,The doctours allovve images. tell vs sir, were not Paulinus, Gregorius, Damascenus, Euthymius, Athanasius, Ambrosius, Isidorus, Hieronymus, Gregorius Nissenus, and S. Basile, doctours of the churche? And haue you not read that Paulinus paynted images in his church, that S. Gregory rebuked him that broke them, that Damascene made a booke of them, that Athanasius accounted them amongest thinges appartayning to the church, and the adourning and setting foorthe of our faith, that Euthymius told the Emperour, that our sauiour Christ euer sithens his incarnation haue ben woorshipped in images? Haue you not read, that S. Ambrose thoughte it lawfull to worship an image, that Hierome had the crosse in Bethlem, and licked it, and kissed it? Haue you not read that Sainct Gregorie liked the image of Abraham sleying his sonne Isaac? that S. Basill counted it Apostolicum, a commaundement or tradition of the Apostles to set vp images in the churches?

Yf yow haue, then can yow not say, all the doctours haue thought the commaundement to extend to vs, and that our images are forbidden by it. For all these doctours, and the whole Catholique church besides haue allwayes allowed images, and neuer thought this commaundement to inhibite our images. Yf yow haue not read so farre in the said fathers, but haue trusted youer englishe doctours, youer Magdeburgenses, youer
M. Caluine, and such Apostatats, begynne nowe to take them in hand. And yf it be too combrouse or longue to ouerrunne them all, then reade the discourse of the seuenth generall Councell kept at Nice: or if that be lothesome and tediouse, reade the fourthe and fift dialogue of M. Alane Cope lately sett foorthe, and this replie of myne. There and here shall yow see that it was neuer inhibited Christē mē by any commaūdemēt of God, in the whole scriptures, to make images and worship them, in such sotte as I declared before.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Fol. 15. a

Nor thinke M. Calfhill, that you haue any aduantage by the Iewes, to whome the lawe was first geuen, and who of congruence should haue the true sense and meaninge of it, because they had no images publiquely in their temples. M. Calfs running to the Ievves and Turkes helpeth hym not. It furdereth yower cause nothīg. They had the lawe, the {pro}phetts, ād Christ him self amōges thē: Yet did not al their skill in the lawe, and prophetts, and miracles of Christe, {per}swade thē that he was the Messias that was the expectation of the gentills, and redemer of the worlde. They did not thinck that he was king of the Iewes, and sauiour of Israell. They did not beleaue that a virgin should bring foorthe a sonne with out breache of her virginitie. They did not vnderstād the mysteries of our faith, their mindes were so addicted to the bare and literall sense of the lawe.
What cōsequution is this M. Calf.
The ievves and Turkes haue no images ī their tēple, ergo Christen men should haue none their churches Lykewise the Turkes vntill this day do not beleaue that the Messias is come. they beleaue not that Christ hath died for the redemption of many: They haue no faith in his passion, no trust in his resurrection, nor hope of his mercy. They haue no sacrament, no baptisme, no supper of our lorde, nor gospell, nor Christ. And because they haue none, shall we haue none? what a sleight of Sathan is this? To bring in more absurdititie, see howe madlie this minister reasoneth. The Iewes and turkes haue no images in their temples, ergo Christen men should haue none in their churches? Yf he might wynne so muche of him, as to thincke, that a sufficient and good argument, then would he haue other in store, as for example. The Iewes and Turkes do not beleaue that the Messias is come, ergo the Christians should
not. The Iewes and Turkes haue no baptisme, ergo the Christiās should haue none. The Iewes and Turkes haue no Sacraments ergo the Christians should haue none. The Iewes keepe not holy the sundaye, ergo the Christians should not. The Iewes and Turkes haue no Gospell nor Christe, ergo the Christians should haue nor Gospell nor Christe. By like reason as M. Calf. concludeth negatiuely, that we must haue no images in our churches, because the Turkes and Iewes had none in their temples, he wil negatyuely conclude al the other, and vpon the graunting of of the first infer the rest, and so bring his disciples a litle and litle to Atheisme.

VVherfor I much maruell that M. Calf. would vse that reason of the Iewes, and alleadge that of the Turkes. It conuinceth him of inexcusable follye, and declareth that he, ād his fellowe protestantes, in this poynt resemble the Iewes and Turkes, as nigh as can be. For as the Iewes and Turkes detested and abhorred images,Heretikes resemble the Ievves and Turkes. so do they. As the Iewes and turkes counted images to be idolls, so do they. As the Iewes and Turkes called the christians idolaters, for hauing and worshipping of images, so doe they. As the Iewes and Turkes thincke it laufull to put away their wyues in case of fornicatiō, and marry another. So would M. Calf. and the protestātes haue it laufull for them. The Iewes and Turkes marry according to Moyses lawe in the degrees of affinitie.Melanch. in locis com 52. So M. Calf. and his fellowes thinke it good that Christians should marry, for he findeth faute with the order of the churche prohibiting mariage within the degrees of affinitie. The Iewes and Turkes haue their Canon of scripture,Melanch. Ibidem. diuerse from the Christians, and reiecte diuerse partes of the old testament, so haue M. Calf. and his fellowes one diuerse from the catholique churche, and reiecte the Machabees, Ecclesiast. and other partes. The Iewes and Turkes doe no penaunce, nor vse any confession of their synnes, no more doth M. Calf. nor his. The Iewes and Turkes detest the crosse as a signe of maledictiō. M. Calf. abhorreth it as a magicall inchauntemēt, as a sorcerous mace, and as a signe of conquest against the Christians. And vnlesse God of his goodnesse, staye the rage of heresie, they will
agre in the other poyntes. As Dauid George beganne,Trinitaries. and the Trinitaries, Anabaptistes, and such as circumcide them selues practisse apace in Polonia. VVherfore seing the commaundemēt of God in Exodus, and other places of scriptures make nothing against images amongest Christen men, seing the doctours teache that the precept of God doth not inhibite our images, but declare the contrary, seing the reason that M. Calf. boroweth of the Iewes and Turkes, is but Iewish and Turkish, and as meate to infringe all the mysteries of our faith and redemption, as to conuince that there should be no images in churches, it is euident that all his babling proueth nothing against the vse of images.

His other position that images doe not teache, is a thinge more boldly auouched, than wysely proued. To euery good Christian,Li. 9 epist. 9, ad Sere. Actio. 4 Nicae. 2. Oratio. in laudes Theodo. martir. Ser. de 40. mart. the auctoritie of the church shalbe a sufficient warrant. And seing S. Gregory calleth them: Lay mens bookes which serue the ignorant in steade of writinges, And Germanus taketh them to be a representation of the stoutnesse of sainctes, and an instruction to teache vs to glorifie God. And Gregorius Nissenus sayeth: Solet etiam pictura tacens in pariete loqui, maxime{que} prodesse. A still picture also in the walle is wounte to speake, and profitte very much: and S. Basile termeth them a still poetrie, and affirmeth, the profitte of pictures and writing to be one, and sayeth: That drawing of thinges lyuely in a table hath stirred many to valiaunt courage, I trust with all indifferēt men. S. Gregorie, Germanus, Gregorius Nissenus, and S. Basill shal more preuayle than the fansie of this protestant, who as he ranne to the Iewes and Turkes euen nowe to proue that we should haue no images in churches: So for proufe of this,Fol. 11. b Amadys. he fleeth to one Amadys a gold smithe of Lōdō, lying in his bed, at the poynt of deathe, when cōmonlye mens senses and wittes fayle them, to proue that images can not teache. And because he tormented with the agonies and panges of death, hauing the crosse presented vnto him to put him in remembraunce of his maker, asked what is the price of an ounce, This wise marchaunte shutteth vp the matter, as thoughe it could not put other in remembrance of Christe, and sayeth.

Fol. 12. a Such is the fruicte that the vnlearned receaue by images, yea though they be of the best sorte. But that you may better vnderstand the weaknesse of his reason, consider his argument: thus in effecte, he sayeth, or must say yf he will proue that images doe not teache.M. Calfs argument that images do not teache. Amadys lying at the poynt of death, when mens witts and senses commonly faile them, was not put in remembrance of Christe by the crosse presented vnto him by his person, ergo men that are whole, and in no such extremitie, can not be put in remembrance by it. And yf this be not, in the iudgement of some whote protestant, a doltishe kinde of reasoning, let him consider it by the like. Some that are almost dead in the lewde lustes of synne, take no commoditie by the worde of God preached by their person: Ergo no man doth. The scholler who hath neither witte nor capacitie, taketh no profitte by his maisters lessons. Ergo none of the rest can. The mā that is desperately sicke of a phrensie can haue no helpe by phisicke, Ergo no other may. And yf these be vayne, and fonde, so thincke of his. For as diuerse take commoditie by the worde of God when it is preached, albeit euery sinful man whose heart is obdurated, doth not, and diuerse schollers receaue, profitte of their maisters lessons, albeit the dullard can not, and many haue helpe by phisick allthough the prontike foole hath not: So albeit Amadys the gold smithe lying at the poynt of death was not put in remembrance of Christe, by the crosse, yet diuerse other are, and stirred to deuotion, and contemplation of the merittes of his passion. For yf Gregorius Nissenus a famous doctour, Lib 22. ca. 73 contra Faust. Manich. Actio. 4 Nicae 2. and lerned bisshope seing the image of Abrahā and his sonne Isaac, tot locis pictū, payncted in so many places, as S. Augustine sayeth, wept when he sawe it, and neuer passed by it, without teares, howe much more will the whole discourse of our sauiour Christes life here incarnate vpon earth being seene of vs, moue all that behold it, to teares, and other furder commoditie? Certes, nowe where charitie is cold, and faithe not feruent, although mē seeing the crosse and image of Christ crucified, doe not weepe, as Gregorius Nissenus did, when he sawe the image of Abraham, offring his sonne, yet no doubte, euery
well disposed man hath some good motion and meditation of the mercy of our sauiour Christe, by the sight of it.

As for that which he obiecteth, against Stephen Gardiner, Fol. 11. b Stephen Gardiner. that he was fowly abused by an image, and founde S. George on horseback in the kinges brode seale, where the kinge him selfe was set on both sides, it is but a mere cauil. The wisdome, learning, grauitie, and experience of that reuerend father and honorable counseller was not to seeke, to knowe S. George on horse backe in batayle, from kinge Henry in peace. But of that hereafter, when I talke of his sclaunderous lies. In the meane tyme consider good readers vpon what groundes this man buildeth his newe doctrine, and as you finde them weake, so imagine of al that is builded.Fol. 19. b To drawe towardes an end of this preface, where he sayeth: that yf the Louanistes had but a māgled piece of such a president for the Pope, as they haue for euery prince, founde in the auncient recordes of London, remayning in the Guild hall, lorde howe would they triumphe? they would desiphire, Fol. 20. a and by Rhethorique resolue euery letter of it, I beseeke you that haue experience of his fyne witte, examine the woordes, which he citeth out of an epistle of
• le •
therius the Pope sent to
• ucius king of England. The woordes that he buildeth vpō, are these.Fol. 19. b A sentence forte out of the Guild hall in Londō. You haue both testaments in youer realme. Take out of them by the grace of God and aduise of youer subiectes, a lawe, and by that lawe through Gods sufferance, rule youer realme, but be you Gods vicar in that kingdome. Here because Eleutherius Pope of Rome willed Lucius king of England (that sent vnto him for lawes to gouerne his people) to take lawes out of the old and newe Testament, and apoynted him to be the vicar of God in that realme, M. Calf. thincketh his owne desperate cause, to be greatly aduauntaged against the Pope. But I pray yow, aske his wisdome, who is of greater authoritie, The man that apoynteth the lawe, or he that receaueth the lawe? The commissioner, or he that geueth the commission? The Lieutenant, or the prince
that apoynteth the Lieutenante? The Viceroye, or the kinge that maketh the viceroy? Yf he acknowledge him that apoynteth the lawe to be of greater authoritie, than the man that receaueth the lawe, and the prince that geueth a commission, to be of higher dignitie,M. Calf. condēnēd by his ovvne sentence brought out of Guild hall in Londō. then the commissioner that receaueth the commission, then must he nedes condemne him self. For by the auncient recordes, remayning in Guild hall in London, it is euident that Eleutherius pope of Rome, apoynted lawes for Lucius kinge of England, and gaue hym authoritie, and commission to be Vicarium Dei, Gods vicar, in that land. And looke howe hier in dignitie he is, that apoynteth the lawe, than he is that receaueth the lawe, he that geueth the commission, than he that receaueth the commission, so higher was Eleutherius then Lucius, and the pope thē the prince. VVhich being so, Lorde howe hath M. Calf. deceaued him self, with a piece of a sentence, brought out of the auncient recordes of Londō, remayning in the Guild hall? howe hath he opened his owne ignorance, and resolued a great piece of his folly? Is it not great pittie for so learned a reader to be so grossely deceaued in so plaīe a matter? Lorde what ouersighte was this of those that had the ouersighte and viewe of his booke before it came to printe with out priuiledge? Must all syphre, and none disiphre, nor by rhetorique resolue euery lettre o •
• his, and by logike proue, that it would make against him? Lorde what a scape was that?

Any of those whome it pleaseth his worship to call the famouse writers of Louayne, Fol. 19. b could haue better aduised his clarkship in this cause, yf he had but once mentioned the matter vnto them: yea the meanest of them all, (that as he sayeth be greate Clearkes, Fol. 19. b bachilers of diuinitye, and studentes of the same, as soone as they tast the good lyquor of Louayne, could haue signified that the sentēce borowed out of the Guild hal of Lōdon would make against him. And (be it spoken with out pride,) the meanest of them all could teache him, and al his moore true diuinitye in one daye, than he or his haue taught the people in sundrie poyntes, these seuen yeares. And albeit
amongest them, we be no more knowē than contemned, yet shal our doings not lacke estimation with the wise, nor intent leese his rewarde with the highest, when he and his shalbe vnknowē, and contemned with the lowest, yf they amend not by tyme.

VVe knowe it to be an olde practise with heretikes,None lerned in the iudgemēt of heretiques but such as sauour thē. to contemne all that fauour not their heresie, and thincke all vnlearned that fansie not their faction. But he that was but yesterday a Cobler, shalbe within fewe monethes, a profounde minister, and great Rabbi, nor vnknowne nor contemned, yf Apollo cast his courtayne aboute him and the spirite inspire him to fauour the procedinges. Yea he shalbe suche a docterlike man, that yf the best of all the papistes were matched wih him, Fol. 19. a The best of the papists not to be matched vvith the simplest protestāt. Lib. 1. cap. 14. Trip. being but the simplest of their side, they should haue great wronge.

For which excessiue pride wel may we with Alexander bisshop of Alexandria, hauing to do with arrogant heretikes crie, O wicked arrogācie, O vnmeasurable madnesse, O rage of vayne logrie, O wisdome of Sathan vehemently inuading their wicked soules. But redresse it we can not. Nor lett them swell like hills in pride, nor be witlesse like Caulfes, nor be full of lyes like lorrels, nor be •• atting like paratts, nor prating like pies, nor clipping like cutte purses, nor scolding like queanes. It is a naturall desease passing with the inheritance. VVherfore yf we will do them good, the only remedy must be to pray vnto allmightie God to geue thē the spirite of humilitie and grace to knowe thē selues. So may it come to passe, that they shall mislike singularitie, and mistrust they owne wisdome, and so by conference with the other, attayne to the knowledge of the truth, which God of his goodnesse graunte.

Yf any willfull protestant, or hotte hereticke myslyke my writing, for that I dippe my penne sometymes ing all, and vse certayne termes, inflamed (as it may seme) with choler,In the epistle. I desire them to consider charitably whose woordes these are. VVillfull wanderer, young scholler, pelting pedler, Synon, Fol. 18. b Ape, seruant to the diuel, Ib • . •• b stuīmblg lade, 40. b hasty hounde,

Furder yf it be not tediouse for them, I desire them to consider charitably whose woordes these are,78. a. b Iezabell, Athalia, insolēt, madde, sauage, wild beast, applied to Irene, in the epistle. Ruffian to Staphilus, disguised gest, sodayne conuert, Apostata, to M.D. Harding, dowghtye to M. Dorman, Rascall, to M. Rastell, Dogges eloquēce, pieuish fansies, colledge of conspiracie, willfull, wittlesse, peruerse confederates, out Iaw • s, lewde Fol. 52. b lyers, image Fol. 13 b mungers, 94. a Romish heretikes, 19 b aduersaries of truthe, 121. a enemies of God, reuerend 68. b asses, Nice 69. a maisters, popish 19. a chaplīs, blinde 94. a beastes, senselesse hipocrites, sausy 36 a mouthes, Apishe 95. b imitatours, 105. b Greasy marchantes, bluddy Ibidē. a coniurers, 18. a Antichristiās, and other suche applied to the Catholiques. And yf they finde them to be their owne propre ministers woordes, issued from the plenifull spōge, and scolding spring of M. Calfs. sprite, lett him graūte vs the same libertye, which they accounte euangelicall in their propre holy preacher, and geue vs, leaue to vse his owne figure of Regestiō, that is to returne backe vpon him, either his owne termes, or the like, and in imitation of his owne Rhetorique, vse his owne figures and phrases of speache, or some equiualent with thē worthely applied to his person, which he vnworthely would lay vpō me. It is reason that they allowe that in another, which they commend in them selues.

Yf any cold Catholique thinck this to hotte, lett him remēbre with what heate the auncient fathers haue written against old heretikes. And yf he fynde these phrases that I vse, or the like in their writinges, lett him beare with me, that in a more perilouse tyme, haue to do with more blasphemouse heretikes. As the phisition by sharpe medicines thincketh to cure longe festred soores: So doe we trust by this kinde of writing to purge the venemouse infection, which this canker of heresie hath bredde, and lodged in mens myndes. S. Augustine declaring, howe one may reproue an other of his faulte, saieth, dilige & dic quod voles. Nullo modo maledictum erit quod specie maledicti sonuerit, In exposi. cap 6 ad Galath. si memineris senserisque te in gladio verbi Dei liberatorem hominis esse velle, ab obsidione vitiorum. I oue and saye what thou wilte. It shall be, by no meanes a taunte that soundeth after the manner of a taunte, yf thou wilt be a delyuerer of a man from the seidge of vice, in the sworde of Gods worde. And certes seing I loue M. Calfhills person, and hate his heresie, as euery Christen man should, I haue vsed that liberty which he hī self tooke, hopinge that as I minister hī occasion to see his errour, so he will gather vnderstandinge, and mislike it, wisdome and deteste it, grace, and desire the mercy of God to pardonne it. Qui attendit contemptores vt corrigat, Augustin. in Psal. 50 nes •• ntes vt doceat, confitentes vt ignoscat, who marketh the contemptuouse that he may punishe them, the ignorant, that he may teache them the būble that confesse their faultes that he may pardonne them. But yf God hath so geuen him ouer to his self will, that for shame of the worlde he wil not chāge his peruerse turkishe faithe, and with the Catholique churche followe the righte faithe, but for eger zeale of contention will followe his blinde guides, he may be well assured that fyer shall come vpon fyer,Idem in Psal. 54. super ardorem dissensionis ardor consumptionis, the flame of consumption vpon the heate of dissension, prepared for all rebellious heretikes with Core, Dathan, and Abiron, by the iust and mercifull iudge, whose name be blessed for euer.
